comment.author: 22575440@N07
comment._content:
is it me or does the river seem high?
 Also, can anyone verify if the street lanterns on the bridge are the same or have they been replaced with replica's?

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/tammybeck] According to this interesting Dublin street lighting site, the gasoliers were "restored" around 1998-2003 - www.archiseek.com/forum/viewtopic.php?f=49&t=3968

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: this was before the bridge was widened so the lamps on this side may have been changed.

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Re your note, Walter Osborne's 1889 painting shows a bookseller near the same spot (just a little further to the left where the hand-cart is). See comments here - [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet/6812334093/]

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Terrific! It is fascinating when these old photos correspond with a painting. Walter Osborne 'The Dublin Streets: a Vendor of Books, 1889' NGI Was there a Dublin tradition of booksellers in this spot, like along the Seine in Paris?

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: This is after the bridge was widened, you can see all the new clean stonework. The older Carlisle bridge had a hump. From wikipedia: In 1877-1880 the bridge was reconstructed ...When the bridge was reopened c.1882 it was renamed for Daniel O'Connell when the statue in his honour was unveiled. So this photo is after the bridge was finished in 1880 and before the statue was finished in 1882.

comment.author: 22919290@N08
comment._content: Very nice seeing the bridge looking so pristine. Would it be nearer to 1882, as how long did it take to complete the statue? There appears to be a works barge of some sort, maybe was something to do with the bridge construction.

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] sorry, you are right - I was looking at the picture on my phone and it wasn't quite as clear.

Interesting to see the ship at Eden quay. This would have been before the Loopline bridge was constructed and the only bridge downstream of here was Butt bridge which at the time was a swivel bridge to allow ships upstream.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: There are construction photos of the bridge in 1879 and 1880 in this pdf. From there: Construction work on the Carlisle Bridge commenced in May 1877 and was completed in August 1880. And here is the Report of the Monument Committee! 1882: The 15th of August was a grand and memorable ceremonial, uniting two objects of great national interest ; the unveiling of the O'Connell Monument and the opening of the Irish Exhibition, in Dublin. Aha! Earlier in 1882: On the 13th of May, 1882, a meeting of the Committee was specially convened, to consider a letter* from the Irish Exhibition Company,Limited, and which had been organized under the presidency of the Eight Hon. Charles Dawson, M.P., Lord Mayor of Dublin, for the promotion of Irish Industries. An enquiry was made as to the possibility of having the O'Connell Monument ready for unveiling on the fast approaching day for opening the Exhibition. In the meantime, the stone work had been completed, and several of the bronze figures had been already placed. The stonework would, I think, be visible in this shot if it was complete, so this picture must be before 13th May 1882, and after August 1880.

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] there's a beautiful photo of the old Butt bridge under construction in that pdf as well - it has an almost Turner-esque quality to it!

comment.author: 56225952@N06
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] 
As readers of 'Ulysses' will know Mr Bloom purchased 'Sweets of Sin' from a hawker at Merchants Arch not far from this spot.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/media-press] notes the tram tracks - yes, the horse-drawn tram (seen at far right) started running along the Quays to Kingsbridge in 1872. The OSI map from 1907 shows this exact track layout here.
